content1.EN:
• Prior Written Consent is authorization by eligible students to allow the institution to disclose information from education records

  • required components of the consent:

    • specify which records may be disclosed

    • state the purpose of the disclosure

    • identify the party to whom the disclosure be made

    • include student signature

    • be dated

The following are examples of instances when the institution does not need prior written consent to disclose records:

  • legitimate educational interest

  • audit or evaluation of compliance with education programs

  • connection with financial aid

  • to organizations conducting studies to improve instruction

  • accrediting organizations

  • parents of dependent students (As long as it is the school's policy to release information to the parents of dependent students, consent is not required. However, FERPA leaves this decision up to the institution.)

  • judicial order or subpoena

  • health/safety emergency

  • directory info (unless restrictions have been requested)

  • releasing results of a disciplinary hearing to a victim of crime

title.EN: When Consent is Not Required - Legitimate Educational Interest

content1.EN:
[CAMPUSCLUE]FERPA gives your school permission to define the term "school official," but requires that it publish this definition in its annual notification.[/CAMPUSCLUE]

  • Can you imagine if every piece of information about a student were kept secret? It would be nearly impossible for the college community to function.

  • Consent is not required in cases in which a [TERM school official]any employee who has responsibilities for the creation, maintenance, and disclosure of information from education records (teachers, administrators, advisors, etc.)[/TERM] needs the records in order to perform his official, educationally-related duties.

  • Access to records must be justifiable. Curiosity doesn't count!

[CASESTUDY Detective Mason from campus security calls the university to get the address and class schedule for a student. Is the university allowed to give it to him? What if Detective Mason says that he has a warrant for the student's arrest?]FERPA regulations consider campus security officials as employees with a “legitimate educational interest” if they are designated as “school officials” by the institution and are operating within the scope of their employment. The warrant would not be necessary in this case. It is advisable for institutions to include campus law enforcement personnel as "school officials" in their annual notification to students.[/CASESTUDY]
